citations.narrative:
During inspection, employees were not easily identifiable as none of the employees had anything on that identified them
as staff. While I was waiting for the licensee to show up to the main tent for inspection, I was not able to see any
employee supervising or monitoring the animals that were on the south side of the tent. It is possible the employees were
somewhere in the tent. The employee assigned to work the tent was difficult to identify due to the number of people in the
tent and the fact that she is not easily identifiable as an employee. In addition, due to the number of members of the
public present at this travel site, one person did not appear to provide sufficient coverage to be able to monitor and
observe all the human/animal interactions that were going on in the tent. 6 employees were working to cover all the
regulated animals that were on site. Three of the employees were working animal rides. One employee was bouncing
back and forth between the animal rides and the main tent where the majority of the regulated animals were housed. One
employee was working in the main tent (northeast side of tent) where the majority of the regulated animals were, but she
was behind a table focusing on taking payment for feed to be handed out. With all the people and animals in the tent she
would not be able to adequately monitor the south side of the tent. Another employee (and only employee) had the
primary duties of working underneath the tent where the majority of the animals were housed. Not having enough
employees and not having the employees being readily identifiable as employees doesn't ensure animal/human safety for
all the regulated animals that were present. If a member of the public were to get injured, they may not be able to find help
from the staff in an adequate amount of time. All employees need to be easily identifiable and there needs to be a
sufficient number of employee to be able to adequately monitor all the human-animal interactions going on. Correct
starting on 7/30/23.

An enclosure housing a spider monkey and a patas was 23 inches away from the outside fence of the tent. During
inspection, I observed two people sticking their arms through the fence and up to the enclosure. Both nonhuman primates
started to reach out to interact with the people that were reaching towards them. The licensee spoke up to stop both
people from reaching out to the primates. However, the barrier doesn't adequately restrict physical contact between the
nonhuman primates and the public. Physical contact between the public and nonhuman primates can result in the spread
of disease between either party. In addition the nonhuman primates could bite and injure any person reaching out. An
adequate barrier must be set up to prevent physical contact between the nonhuman primates and the public. Correct
starting on 7/30/23.
Note: This was corrected during inspection.

During inspection, a pile of dry food near the bags of food was observed in one of the transport trailers. It appeared a bag
of food had been opened and the food spilled onto the floor of the trailer. The exposed food could attract rodents and
other pests. Spilled food and the food storage area must be cleaned up quickly and sufficiently so to not attract rodents
and other pests. Correct starting on 7/30/23.

A camel used for camel rides did not have any shelter. The licensee stated the camel had a tent that covered
approximately half the enclosure, but the tent blew over last night. There is nothing that provides any cover from the
shade or elements of the weather. The lack of sufficient shelter decreases the protection of the camel from sunlight and
inclement weather and increases the risk of their discomfort. The licensee must ensure that adequate natural or artificial
shelter is provided for all of the animals in outdoor enclosures as required in this section at all times. Correct starting on
7/30/23.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
End of report.
n

narrative:
2.131(d)(2) 
   
Handling of animals. 
During inspection, employees were not easily identifiable as none of the employees had anything on that identified them 
as staff. While I was waiting for the licensee to show up to the main tent for inspection, I was not able to see any 
employee supervising or monitoring the animals that were on the south side of the tent. It is possible the employees were 
somewhere in the tent. The employee assigned to work the tent was difficult to identify due to the number of people in the 
tent and the fact that she is not easily identifiable as an employee. In addition, due to the number of members of the 
public present at this travel site, one person did not appear to provide sufficient coverage to be able to monitor and 
observe all the human/animal interactions that were going on in the tent. 6 employees were working to cover all the 
regulated animals that were on site. Three of the employees were working animal rides. One employee was bouncing 
back and forth between the animal rides and the main tent where the majority of the regulated animals were housed. One 
employee was working in the main tent (northeast side of tent) where the majority of the regulated animals were, but she 
was behind a table focusing on taking payment for feed to be handed out. With all the people and animals in the tent she 
would not be able to adequately monitor the south side of the tent. Another employee (and only employee) had the 
primary duties of working underneath the tent where the majority of the animals were housed. Not having enough 
employees and not having the employees being readily identifiable as employees doesn't ensure animal/human safety for 
all the regulated animals that were present. If a member of the public were to get injured, they may not be able to find help 
from the staff in an adequate amount of time. All employees need to be easily identifiable and there needs to be a 
sufficient number of employee to be able to adequately monitor all the human-animal interactions going on. Correct 
starting on 7/30/23. 
3.79(d) 
   
Mobile or traveling housing facilities. 
An enclosure housing a spider monkey and a patas was 23 inches away from the outside fence of the tent. During 
inspection, I observed two people sticking their arms through the fence and up to the enclosure. Both nonhuman primates 
started to reach out to interact with the people that were reaching towards them. The licensee spoke up to stop both 
people from reaching out to the primates. However, the barrier doesn't adequately restrict physical contact between the 
nonhuman primates and the public. Physical contact between the public and nonhuman primates can result in the spread 
of disease between either party. In addition the nonhuman primates could bite and injure any person reaching out. An 
adequate barrier must be set up to prevent physical contact between the nonhuman primates and the public. Correct 
starting on 7/30/23.

Note: This was corrected during inspection. 
3.125(c) 
   
Facilities, general. 
During inspection, a pile of dry food near the bags of food was observed in one of the transport trailers. It appeared a bag 
of food had been opened and the food spilled onto the floor of the trailer. The exposed food could attract rodents and 
other pests. Spilled food and the food storage area must be cleaned up quickly and sufficiently so to not attract rodents 
and other pests. Correct starting on 7/30/23. 
3.127(a) 
   
Facilities, outdoor. 
A camel used for camel rides did not have any shelter. The licensee stated the camel had a tent that covered 
approximately half the enclosure, but the tent blew over last night. There is nothing that provides any cover from the 
shade or elements of the weather. The lack of sufficient shelter decreases the protection of the camel from sunlight and 
inclement weather and increases the risk of their discomfort. The licensee must ensure that adequate natural or artificial 
shelter is provided for all of the animals in outdoor enclosures as required in this section at all times. Correct starting on 
7/30/23. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee. 
 
End of report.

species.common: DOMESTIC PIG / POTBELLY PIG / MICRO PIG
